title: Protocol for studying microbiome impact on host energy and reproduction in Drosophila
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Rearing flies with and without native gut bacteria
Timing: 15–18 days
The following procedure is used to prepare flies with and without native gut microbiota.
Collect the eggs.
Place embryo collection cage on a CO2 anesthetizing flypad at the minimal flow, necessary to anaesthetize flies. Transfer mature adult females (5–8 days old) from 6-8 bottles (see above) into the embryo collection cage (one cage per treatment). Use Yeast Extract–Peptone–Dextrose (YPD) plates to close the cage.
Note: We use YPD plates to promote egg laying without supplementation of yeasts.
Keep the flies on CO2 anesthetizing flypad for 1.5 min.
Remove the cage from the anesthetizing apparatus and let the flies lay eggs on the YPD plate for 45 min - 1 h at 25°C.
Note: This step (synchronization) allows flies to release the old eggs and avoid larval hatching prior to removal procedure of gut bacteria (step 3). Lack of synchronization can lead to bacterial contamination of the germ-free vials.
Repeat steps 1 b and c (2nd synchronization).
Optional: Change the laying plate to a new YPD plate for a 2nd round of laying.
Anesthetize the flies in the cage, replace the synchronization plate to a new YPD plate and incubate for ∼3 h at RT to get the desired number of eggs.
Note: The time of egg laying depends on the fly’s stock.
Discard the flies or keep them for recolonization treatment (see below).
Remove flies that are stuck to the agar.
Prepare control flies (flies with native bacteria intact).
Add double distilled water (DDW) to the plate with eggs (from step 1) and gently detach the eggs from the surface using a paint brush.

Rinse the eggs, transfer them to the cell strainer (100 μm) and keep the strainer in the plate with DDW during the transfer procedure (step 2 c).
Note: To maximize the collection of eggs from the plate, repeat steps 2 a, b.
Pick up (∼20–30) eggs on the tip of the paint brush and gently transfer them to the surface of sterile food in vials.
Note: To prevent egg drying during the transfer, the strainer should be kept wet inside the 35 mm tissue culture plate.
Remove gut bacteria by dechorionation to generate germ-free (GF) flies.
Add 3% sodium hypochlorite solution to the plate with eggs (from step 1), gently detach the eggs from the surface using a paint brush and incubate the eggs for 2 min.
Collect the cells by transferring them through the cell strainer (100 μm).
Collect the remaining eggs from the plate by washing the plate again with 70% ETOH and place the strainer into a 35 mm plate with 70% ETOH.
In the biological safety cabinet prepare one culture plate (35 mm) with sterile 70% ETOH and 3 culture plates (35 mm) with sterile DDW.
Transfer the strainer with the eggs into a biological safety cabinet.
Use forceps to place the strainer into a new culture plate with 70% ETOH.
Wash the eggs three times with sterile DDW. Each time transfer the cell strainer to a new plate with DDW.
Use the paint brush to gently transfer dechorionated (∼20–30) eggs onto the surface of sterile food.
Recolonize the eggs with native gut bacteria.
Prepare vials with GF eggs, as described in step 3.
Transfer five males (from step 1 d) to the vial with GF eggs.

Let males “contaminate” the food with native gut bacteria for 1–2 days at 25°C, 60% humidity, 12 h light:12 h dark cycle controlled incubator and then discard them.
Incubate all the vials (control and GF with and without recolonization) at 25°C, 60% humidity, 12 h light:12 h dark cycle controlled incubator and follow fly development (larval development, pupariation, and eclosion).
Note: In GF flies, we expect a developmental delay of 1–2 days.
Two days after eclosion transfer newly emerged flies (day 0–2) into new vials and incubate for 5 more days at 25°C, 60% humidity in a 12 h light:12 h dark cycle controlled incubator.
Note: GF flies should be transferred in the sterile conditions.
Optional: Combine flies from 2 vials in 1 new vial.
Note: It is recommended to keep the original vials for later test of germ-free conditions (step 8).
Collect flies and tissue for subsequent analyses.
Collect separately males and females into 2 mL Eppendorf tube, weigh and freeze immediately in a dry ice/liquid nitrogen.
For metabolic profiling: 40–50 flies per sample;
For targeted metabolomics: 10 flies per sample.
Transfer to −80°C for storage.
Dissect ovaries:
For metabolic profiling: 40–50 ovaries per sample. Freeze immediately on dry ice.
For targeted metabolomics: 10 ovaries per sample. Freeze immediately on dry ice.
For staging: collect 15–20 ovaries to ice-cold phosphate buffered saline (PBS) and proceed to DAPI staining (steps 9–21).
Check germ-free conditions of the food by plating food samples from the used vials on YPD plates.
Optional: Confirm germ-free conditions using PCR with universal 16S ribosomal DNA primers (for example, 8F and 939R oligonucleotides, see key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]). The PCR is performed on fly homogenate. Product size ∼940, annealing step at 60°C.

Optional: Confirm the expected delay in larval development under germ-free conditions. Note that the removal of gut microbiota by dechorionation typically results in delayed pupation which depends on the choice of diet (Fridmann-Sirkis et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]).
Analysis of ovarian development
Timing: 2 h
This step enables evaluation of ovarian development by staging ovarian egg chambers. Number of mature oocytes in the ovary indicates the status of the oogenesis process.
Dissect 15–20 pairs of ovaries from each treatment and transfer them to the Eppendorf tube with 0.5 mL of PBSx1.
Let the ovaries settle down and aspirate PBS.
Add 3.7% formaldehyde (FA) to fixate the ovaries and incubate for 20 min at 25°C with shaking (∼25–27 rpm).
Note: Fixation solution must be prepared freshly before each use.
Let the ovaries settle down, discard FA and wash twice with 1.5 mL PBS.
Pause point: The procedure can be paused at this point and the sample can be kept in 4°C for a few days.
Discard the PBS and incubate the ovaries with 0.5 mL 1% Triton (in PBS) for 30 min.
Wash twice with PBS. Discard the last wash and add 1 mL PBS.
Collect the ovaries with Pasteur pipette and place them on microscope slide.
Place the ovaries in the center and carefully dry the liquid around them using disposable wipers.
Add one drop of Vectashield mounting medium with DAPI.
Arrange the ovaries on the slide for imaging using forceps.
Use pin holders to gently separate the ovarioles from each other, keeping the ovary intact and cover the slide with coverslip.
Take images of the DAPI-stained ovaries using fluorescent inverted microscope (4× magnification).
Evaluate ovarian development by scoring the number of egg chambers at different stages in each ovary (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]) (Elgart et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]; Gnainsky et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]).

Figure 1. Staging of DAPI-stained ovaries
(A) Representative images of DAPI-stained ovaries of 6-day OrR females, control (Ctrl) and germ-free with and without gut bacteria (GF+bac and GF, respectively). Scale bar 100 μm.
(B) Numbers of stage 11–14 egg chambers in ovary for cases in (A). Data are represented as mean ± SEM.
Quantitative analysis of energy-carrying molecules
Timing: 4 days: 21 h for step 22, 21 h for step 23, 40 min for step 24, and 7.5 min per sample for step 25
This step aims at analyzing the microbiome impact on energy production by measuring the levels of energy-carrying molecules using quantitative LC-MS/MS. The protocol below describes the specific steps for ATP and ADP measurements (we also used this protocol for GTP and GDP).
Note: Prepare fresh solutions on the day of use. Calculate the required volumes, taking into consideration the number of samples, dilutions, washes, etc.
Preparation of sample extracts.
Add 1 mL of 70%-aqueous methanol (MeOH) to frozen flies/tissue (from step 7).
Note: 70%-MeOH should be pre-chilled to ∼4°C before use (on ice or in a refrigerator).
Homogenize tissue using handheld pestle motor mixer on ice for 1–2 min.
Prepare 1 mM aqueous solution of internal standard 13C10-ATP.
Add 5 μL 1 mM aqueous solution of internal standard 13C10-ATP to each extract.
Agitate the mixture in Thermo Mixer C at 9°C and 1,000 rpm for 10 min.
Centrifuge at 21,000 × g at 4°C for 5 min to pellet proteins and cell debris, and transfer the supernatant to a clean 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube, without disturbing the precipitate.
Evaporate the supernatant using a speedvac.
Note: To remove MeOH usually takes ∼2 h.
Freeze the residual aqueous solution by immersing Eppendorf’s bottom in liquid nitrogen for 1 min.

Place frozen sample in the freeze dryer for complete evaporation overnight (∼18 h).
Pause point: Evaporated extract can be stored at −80°C for at least two weeks.
Alternatives: MeOH evaporation can be performed by a stream of nitrogen gas at 25°C.
Critical: Organic solvents, such as MeOH are highly toxic. The use of these agents should be performed in a fume hood. During speedvac evaporation of these organic solvents, the exhaust of the vacuum pump should be drawn to the fume hood or to exhaust of a proper scavenging line.
Purification of extracts by Solid-phase extraction (SPE).
Note: Purification of nucleotides on polymeric weak anion column is required to remove all other components of the sample that significantly reduce signal intensity in mass spectrometer (matrix effect).
Prepare following solutions:
1 mM aqueous solution of internal standard 13C10-ATP.
DDW.
Methanol (MeOH).
50%-aqueous MeOH.
Formic acid/MeOH/DDW (2:25:73 v/v/v).
Ammonia/MeOH/DDW (8:25:67 v/v/v).
Note: Ammonia is 25%-aqueous ammonia solution.
Ammonia/MeOH/DDW (8:50:42 v/v/v).
Condition SPE column.
Place the column on a vacuum manifold.
Add 1 mL MeOH and let it flow through the column at a rate of about 1 mL/min.
Add 1 mL formic acid/MeOH/DDW (2:25:73, v/v/v), and let it flow at the same rate.
Wash the column with 1 mL DDW at the same rate flow.
Purify the sample.
Add 200 μL water to re-suspend the sample pellet, vortex shortly. Load the suspension onto the SPE column, let it flow through at about 0.5 mL/min.
Wash the column with 1 mL water, then with 1 mL 50% MeOH at about 1 mL/min.
Elute the sample with 1 mL ammonia/MeOH/water (8:25:67, v/v/v), and then 1 mL ammonia/MeOH/water (8:50:42, v/v/v) (see preparation in 23 a), collecting the eluates.
Evaporate the collected elutes as described in steps 22 g–i.

Critical: Use flows as drops and not as stream to avoid reduction in metabolite recovery and purification quality.
Note: If there is no liquid flow in steps b and c, use a slight vacuum suction to initiate the process.
Pause point: Evaporated extract can be stored at −80°C for at least 2 weeks.
Generating a standard curve.
Prepare Mobile phase A: 10 mM ammonium acetate and 5 mM ammonium bicarbonate buffer, pH 7.65 (adjusted with 10% acetic acid).
Prepare Mobile phase B: acetonitrile.
Prepare ATP and ADP standard solutions for the standard curve:
Dissolve pre-weighted amounts of ATP and ADP in DDW to get 1 mg/mL solutions of each.
50 μg/mL (Stock solution): Mix 5 μL of each 1 mg/mL solution with 95 μL DDW.
25 μg/mL (Solution I): Dilute 50 μL of each 50 μg/mL stock solution with 50 μL DDW.
2.5 μg/mL (Solution II): Dilute 10 μL of each 25 μg/mL solution with 90 μL of DDW.
0.25 μg/mL (Solution III): Dilute 10 μL of 2.5 μg/mL solution with 90 μL of DDW.
10 μg/mL standard solution: Add 40 μL of Solution I to 50 μL of mobile phase A (step 24), add 10 μL of 1 mM internal standard 13C10-ATP (step 23 a i).
5 μg/mL standard solution: Add 20 μL of Solution I to 70 μL of mobile phase A (step 24), add 10 μL of 1 mM internal standard 13C10-ATP (step 23 a i).
1 μg/mL standard solution: Add 40 μL of Solution II to 50 μL of mobile phase A (step 24), add 10 μL of 1 mM internal standard 13C10-ATP (step 23 a i).

0.5 μg/mL standard solution: Add 20 μL of Solution II to 50 μL of mobile phase A (step 24), add 10 μL of 1 mM internal standard 13C10-ATP (step 23 a i).
0.1 μg/mL standard solution: Add 40 μL of solution III to 50 μL of mobile phase A (step 24), add 10 μL of 1 mM internal standard 13C10-ATP (step 23 a i).
0.01 μg/mL standard solution: Add 4 μL of solution III to 50 μL of mobile phase A (step 24), add 10 μL of 1 mM internal standard 13C10-ATP (step 23 a i).
Note: Final concentration of the internal standard – 100 μM.
Place the prepared solution after short vortex into 250-μL inserts of LC-MS vials.
Measuring the levels of ATP and ADP using UPLC-MSMS.
Preparation of samples.
Re-suspend dried samples in 50 μL of mobile phase A, vortex shortly.
Centrifuge at 21,000 × g at 4°C for 5 min to rid of possible insoluble material, and transfer the supernatant to a clean 250-μL insert of LC-MS vials without disturbing the precipitate.
Run LC-MS/MS analysis using system setup as described in materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] section.
Acquisition and analysis of data is done using MassLynx and TargetLynx softwares (version 4.1), respectively.
Detection of the compounds is done using multiple-reaction monitoring (MRM) parameters (Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3]).

Preparing solutions for biphasic extraction (for metabolomics and lipidomics)
Timing: 4 h
Solutions cooled to −20°C:
TMBE (methyl-tertbutyl-ether): MeOH (3:1, v/v) containing following internal standards: 0.1 μg/mL of phosphatidylcholine (17:0/17:0), 0.4 μg/mL of phosphatidylethanolamine (17:0/17:0), 0.15 nmol/mL of ceramide/sphingoid internal standard mixture I, 0.0267 μg/mL d5-TG internal standard mixture I and 0.1 μg/mL palmitic acid-13C.
H2O: MeOH (3:1, v/v), containing following internal standards: cell-free amino acid mixture - 13C,15N.
Solutions at 25°C:
MeOH: H2O (1:1, v/v) (for dissolving dry polar sample).
TMBE.

Running buffers for the UPLS-MS machines.
Polar running phase.
Mobile phase A: 20 mM ammonium carbonate with 0.1% ammonia hydroxide in H2O: acetonitrile (80:20, v/v).
Mobile phase B: Acetonitrile.
Note: Adjust pH in mobile phase A, using ammonia solution 25% to pH=9.4. Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Semipolar running phase:
Mobile phase A: Acetonitrile: H2O (95:5, v/v). with 0.1% formic acid.
Mobile phase B: Acetonitrile with 0.1% formic acid.
Lipid running phase:
Mobile phase A: H2O: acetonitrile: 2-propanol 46:38:16 (v/v/v) with 1% 1 M NH4Ac, 0.1% acetic acid.
Mobile phase B: H2O: Acetonitrile: 2-propanol 1:69:30 (v/v/v) with 1% 1 M NH4Ac, 0.1% acetic acid. (also used to dissolve dried lipid sample for injection).
Note: For solution preparations, use DDW from Milli-Q® Water Purification System supplemented with LC-Pak® Polisher.
Preparation of extracts for metabolomics and lipidomics
Timing: 1 day
The following procedure extracts a wide range of metabolites from fly ovary liophilaed powder prior to the LC-MS analysis. Each extraction contains analytes from a particular biological sample and can be applied to dissected tissues, organs or whole flies.
Note: If the samples to be collected during several days, it is critical to snap-freeze all the samples at the same hours during the collection day to avoid metabolic effects of the circadian clock in the study subjects.
Lyophilize snap-frozen samples of flies and ovaries overnight (∼18 h) in 2 mL safe-lock microcentrifuge tubes.
Add two metal balls into each tube and grind the samples to a fine powder by shaking in a homogenizer mixer mill at 30 Hz for two minutes.
Pre-cool (−20°C) extraction mixture (TMBE: MeOH, (3:1, v/v) containing following internal standards: 0.1 μg/mL of phosphatidylcholine (17:0/17:0), 0.4 μg/mL of phosphatidylethanolamine (17:0/17:0), 0.15 nmol/mL of ceramide/sphingoid internal standard mixture I, 0.0267 μg/mL d5-TG internal standard mixture I and 0.1 μg/mL palmitic acid-13C.

Add 1 mL of the pre-cooled extraction mixture to each sample tube.
Critical: This step should be done as quickly as possible due to the low viscosity of TMBE. To avoid extraction mixture dripping out from the pipette tip, we suggest pre-wetting the tip before use with extraction solution by pipetting it in and out.
Mix immediately using a vortex mixer until the tissue is homogenized in the extraction mixture.
Note: This step is crucial since it is used to precipitate the proteins and inactivate their enzymatic activities.
Incubate samples in a sonicator bath for 30 min at 4°C. Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]
Vortex samples every 10 min.
Add 500 μL of H2O: MeOH (3:1, v/v), containing the following internal standards: Cell-Free amino acid mixture - 13C,15N to each sample tube.
Vortex for 0.5 min.
Centrifuge samples at 20,000 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Note: At this point, there are two immiscible liquid phases with a solid pellet in the bottom of the tubes.
Note: For high-quality extraction, the starting material should be ground into fine homogenous powder. If there is no suitable available homogenizer, it is possible to use mortar and pestle.
Critical: Carefully handle the tubes to prevent mixing the two liquid phases and disrupting the precipitated pellet.
Transfer 500 μL from the upper, lipid-containing phase, into a labeled 2 mL microcentrifuge tube.
Start evaporation using speedvac without heating.
Add to remaining fraction 0.5 mL of TMBE and repeat extraction process as described in steps 29–35.
Transfer 500 μL of upper phase (lipid-enriched) from 2nd extraction into the tube with the first portion and continue evaporation using speedvac without heating.
Transfer 400 μL from the lower phase (polar and semi-polar metabolites) into a labeled 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube and evaporate using speedvac without heating.

Note: The evaporation of the organic samples can be done by a gentle stream of nitrogen.
Pause point: Dried polar extracts can be immediately used for UPLC-MS analysis (steps 48–50) or stored for several weeks at −80°C.
Remove the remaining aqueous/lipid phase from the protein pellet by pipetting off the excess volume.
Note: Protein pellets can be used for normalization and other analyses.
Pause point: Protein pellets can be stored at −80°C for further analysis.
Analysis of lipids using UPLC-qToF-IMS
Timing: Running time 25 min per sample
Steps 45–47 enable chromatographic separation of metabolites, determining their mass spectra and identifying specific lipid species.
Dissolve lipid extracts (step 42) before injection into lipid gradient analysis.
Add 250 μL of Mobile phase B, described in step 28 c ii, to dry pellet from step 42.
Vortex.
Sonicate in sonicator bath for 5 min at 4°C and vortex again.
Centrifuge at 20,000 × g for 10 min.
Transfer 150 μL into HPLC glass vial for injection.
Analyze the lipid extract by the ACQUITY UPLC system coupled to a Vion IMS qToF mass spectrometer.
Insert the glass HPLC vials into a cooled autosampler (6°C).
Using a UPLC system running at a flow rate of 400 μL/min, inject 1 μL of sample on a ACQUITY UPLC BEH C8 column (2.1 × 100 mm, i.d., 1.7 μm) (Waters Corp., MA, USA) at 40°C.
Use the mobile phases gradient (Table 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl4]), for the chromatographic separation.

Acquire the mass spectra in the positive and negative ionization modes using an MS instrument covering the mass range between 50 and 1,800 m/z.
Analysis of the output.
Identify lipids by comparison of their retention time, accurate mass, fragmentation pattern and ion mobility values to existing in-house lipid library, as well as to standards when available using UNIFI 1.9.2 software.

Export the result table.
Analysis of polar using UPLC-Q-Exactive Orbitrap
Timing: Running time 23 min per sample
The following procedure enables separation and identification of polar metabolites.
Dissolve polar extract (step 43) before injection into polar gradient analysis.
Add 150 μL of MeOH: H2O, 1:1 (v/v) to dry pellet.
Mix by vortex.
Sonicate in sonicator bath for 5 min at 4°C.
Centrifuge at 20,000 × g for 10 min.
Transfer supernatant to a new 1.5 mL tube and centrifuge again.
Transfer remaining 100 μL into HPLC glass vial for injection.
Analyze the polar extract by the ACQUITY UPLC system coupled to Q-Exactive Orbitrap.
Insert the glass vials into a cooled autosampler (6°C).
Use a UPLC system running at a flow rate of 200 μL/min inject 1 μL per sample on a SeQuant Zic-pHilic (150 mm × 2.1 mm) column with the SeQuant guard column (20 mm × 2.1 mm) at 35°C. Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]
Use the Mobile phases gradient described in Table 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl5] for the chromatographic separation.

Acquire the mass spectra in the negative ionization mode using an MS instrument covering the mass range between 50 and 750 m/z.
Analysis of the output.
Process the data using TraceFinder software, identifying the detected compounds by retention time and fragments.
Verify using an in-house-generated polar mass spectra library.
Analysis of semi-polar co using UPLC-qToF-IMS
Timing: Running time 28 min per sample
Steps 51 and 52 extend the UPLC-qToF-IMS analysis (above) to semi-polar metabolites.
Analyze the polar extract on the ACQUITY UPLC system coupled to a Vion IMS qToF mass spectrometer.
Insert the glass vials into a cooled autosampler (6°C).
Use a UPLC system running at a flow rate of 300 μL/min Inject 1 μL of sample on a ACQUITY UPLC BEH C18 column (2.1 × 100 mm, i.d., 1.7 μm) at 35°C.

Use the Mobile phases gradient (Table 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl6]) for the chromatographic separation.

Acquire the mass spectra in the positive and negative ionization modes using an MS instrument covering the mass range between 50 and 2,000 m/z.
Analysis of the output.
Identify metabolites by comparison of Retention time, accurate mass and ion mobility of the peaks to the in-house semi-polar library (UNIFI 1.9.2).
Export the result table.
